context.text: Our recent work [3] has focused on developing a set of software tools that allow us to collect in-field defect samples from a wider set of imagers.
In our most recent study [3] we had proposed a defect-tracing algorithm that can automatically detect the first appearance of a defect by analyzing a sequence of color images.

As one can expect, if a pixel is defective, interpolating with the inaccurate response of the pixel will spread the error to neighboring pixels; thus we will observe a cluster of defective pixels in color images as shown in Figure 4 [3].

By collecting the image-wide interpolation error we can derive the interpolation error Probability Density Function (PDF), \$p_{E}(e)\$ the probability of a good pixel given its value \$y_{k}\$ and the interpolation \$z_{k}\$, and the Cumulative Density Function (CDF), \$P_{E}(e)\$, which provide a statistical measure of the state of the defective pixel, are given in Equations (2) and (3) (see [3] for the detailed derivation of these equations).

Previous simulation results [3] have shown that a window length of 5 or 7 tends to attenuate the detection date whereas with a length of 3, more emphasis is put on the recent images and older imagers are ignored.

The required feedback amount for the proposed precoder is also less than the system in [18].

Our simulation studies suggest that the additional degrees of freedom available in our approach enable our scheme to provide significantly better performance than that in [17], [18] while using a lower feedback rate.
